texts.definition: Abilities that let agents perform actions not readily available to others.
markups: <style="Definition">Abilities that let agents perform actions not readily available to others.</style>

Many games have different sets of actions possible for different players. The actions one player has, or possibly a few players have, are <style="CurrentLink">Privileged Abilities</style> in that they allow different tactics during gameplay, and allow different forms of goals to be sought.

Class-based <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Warhammer%20Fantasy%20Roleplay">Warhammer Fantasy Roleplay</link></style> limit abilities so that they are privileged to specific classes. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Computer-based%20Roleplaying%20Games">Computer roleplaying games</link></style>, such as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NetHack">NetHack</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Torchlight">Torchlight</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dragon%20Age%20series">Dragon Age series</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Neverwinter%20Nights%20series">Neverwinter Nights series</link></style>, and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diablo%20series">Diablo series</link></style>, continued to make use of <style="CurrentLink">Privileged Abilities</style> by making certain actions only available to specific classes, for example, only allowing wizards to cast spells. This has also been carried over to some <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Massively%20Multiplayer%20Online%20Games">Massively Multiplayer Online Games</link></style>, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/World%20of%20Warcraft">World of Warcraft</link></style>.

Many First-Person Shooters, e.g. the Doom and Quake series give players a sort of Privileged Abilities in the various weapons they have access to. Half-Life 2 does likewise but also includes a gravity gun while the Portal series only lets players use a portal gun that can create inter-spatial portal between different parts of levels. The Legend of Zelda series, and to an even greater extent the Just Cause series, gives players the possibility of doing movement by using grappling hooks that nobody other inhabitants can do. One type of Privileged Abilities revolve around manipulation of game time: the Max Payne series gives players the possibility of slowing time for all enemies through engaging in bullet time while Braid and later installments of the Prince of Persia series lets players rewind time.

Online multiplayer <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:FPS%20Games">First-Person Shooters</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Return%20to%20Castle%20Wolfenstein:%20Enemy%20Territory">Return to Castle Wolfenstein: Enemy Territory</link></style> or the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Battlefield%20series">Battlefield series</link></style> use the same method of dividing special abilities, such as repairing vehicles or providing air strikes, to specific classes. Return to <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Castle%20Wolfenstein:%20Enemy%20Territory">Castle Wolfenstein: Enemy Territory</link></style> further provides new actions as players gain experience in various activities. The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Left%204%20Dead%20series">Left 4 Dead series</link></style> give the various "special infected" various <style="CurrentLink">Privileged Abilities</style>, e.g. acids spits and the ability to steer ridden enemies, and the players with these abilities need to used them together to increase their chances of winning.

The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Board%20Games">Board Game</link></style> <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/History%20of%20the%20World">History of the World</link></style> uses <style="Link"><link="cards">Cards</link></style> with special abilities that can be played only on certain turns in order to follow loosely the historical development of civilizations. In <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Battlestar%20Galactica:%20The%20Board%20Game">Battlestar Galactica: The Board Game</link></style> players get special actions they can perform based upon which character they are playing. The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Card%20Games">Card Game</link></style> <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Race%20for%20the%20Galaxy">Race for the Galaxy</link></style> gives players different starting positions by randomizing starting <style="Link"><link="cards">Cards</link></style> and this give players <style="CurrentLink">Privileged Abilities</style>, at least to begin with.

Privileged Abilities are privileged due to some Agents have Abilities that others do not. This can be done in two ways: one is that other agents simply do not have the Abilities and the other is that one has Improved Abilities whose effects cannot easily be compensated by skillful play. In Multiplayer Games, the other agents may be other players but the pattern can also be all types of games to differentiate between players' Abilities and that of Non-Player Characters or Enemies; this may include the NPCs having Abilities that players do not have. A particular case is that of a Game System Player, these docile players typically have Privileged Abilities due to their role as more or less passive threats to the other players. Privileged Abilities may also be used to differentiate between ordinary Enemies and Boss Monsters. Games with Game Masters provide these with many Privileged Abilities since these can access and modify game states and Game Worlds in ways players cannot. Entitled Players do the same but limit these. Disregarding Entitled Players and Game Masters, the design choices regarding Privileged Abilities can be divided into three main categories of which the two latter overlaps to a certain degree: the actual nature of the actions they provide, how the actions are made available, and which players have access to the actions. Putting strict limits on the number of times Privileged Abilities can be used make them Non-Renewable Resources.

Privileged Abilities can take many different forms. Privileged Movement is a common example, which can include being able to ignore certain Zones of Control or Obstacles, enter Safe Havens, use grappling hooks, do special types of Jumping such as double jumps or wall jumps (both found in the Super Mario series), use Quick Returns, drive Vehicles, initiate Quick Travel, being able to use or create Warp Zones (as Chell can do in the Portal series), or act as Spawn Points (as squad leaders in Battlefield 2). Giving players special actions in Combat, such as Combos, are also common. Others, somewhat more uncommon include Construction, Crafting, and other ways of creating or manipulating Resources, especially when these means becoming a source of Renewable Resources; restoring Health can be considered an example of this. Being able to switch between different Vision Modes (as is possible in the Alien vs Predator series or Batman: Arkham Asylum) does not directly provide new actions but can hugely change how players perceive Game Worlds and what they can do within them. Activate or deactivating Alarms is an even more uncommon Privileged Ability but when it exists often directly influences the overall gameplay. Trumps provide Privileged Abilities to a suit of Cards in games with Trick Taking. Games with Drawing Stacks are Discard Piles can have Privileged Abilities in letting players look through them, pick Cards or Tiles from any place within them, or take from the Discard Piles when in ordinary cases one should have taken from the Drawing Stacks. On a very general level, being allowed to treat actions as Interruptible Actions, being able to reverse Irreversible Events or perform Game Time Manipulation, being given Extra Chances, having Open-Ended Die Rolls, or the power to create Fudged Results are all examples of Privileged Abilities. In some cases, even the option of performing No-Op actions can be a Privileged Ability.

Some Privileged Abilities, for example being in control of Player-Decided Distributions of Rewards and Penalties, are not direct actions during gameplay but rather let players affect the evaluation functions of a game. Privileged Abilities can also be passive, in which case they do not give players new actions they can perform but rather let them do actions they already have in situations where other could not do them. The most common of this type of Privileged Abilities is probably to have lessened effects or complete Invulnerabilities to Penalties or Environmental Effects such as Damage (Team Fortress 2 shows how Invulnerabilities can be temporarily given to combatants without unbalancing the game as a whole through allowing medics to activate Ã¼bercharges).

Certain Privileged Abilities relate to the availability of information: having knowledge about Secret Resources, being allowed to look at another players' Hands or having Units with less Fog of War or different Line of Sight rules than other Units for example. Another example of information-related Privileged Abilities are those that provide ways of viewing Game Worlds so that some game elements become Diegetically Outstanding Features (the eagle vision in the Assassin's Creed series is an example of this). These Abilities may be designed to be either active in the sense that getting the information is a gameplay action or passive in that they can always be accessed and mainly affect how players can perform other actions.

<style="CurrentLink">Privileged Abilities</style> can either be present at the beginning of gameplay or made available as <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="improved-abilities">Improved Abilities</link></style> (e.g. through <style="Link"><link="unlocking">Unlocking</link></style> them or <style="Link"><link="alien-space-bats">Alien Space Bats</link></style>). Entering <style="Link"><link="chargers">Chargers</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="controllers">Controllers</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="environmental-effects">Environmental Effects</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="installations">Installations</link></style>, or taking <style="Link"><link="power-ups">Power-Ups</link></style> can give or modify these <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style> while in their vicinity, while having <style="Link"><link="territories">Territories</link></style> with <style="Link"><link="location-fixed-abilities">Location-Fixed Abilities</link></style>, or simply <style="Link"><link="area-control">Area Control</link></style> of such <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style> can be another form of <style="CurrentLink">Privileged Abilities</style> if the <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style> are not provided in many locations. In this case, the activation of <style="CurrentLink">Privileged Abilities</style> is tied to specific locations in games and gaining the <style="CurrentLink">Privileged Abilities</style> can become a question of knowing <style="Link"><link="strategic-locations">Strategic Locations</link></style>. While <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style> may have their own <style="CurrentLink">Privileged Abilities</style>, some games (e.g. the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%20series">Fallout series</link></style>) gives players extra <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> for acquiring <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style> in the form of <style="Link"><link="companions">Companion</link></style>-specific <style="CurrentLink">Privileged Abilities</style>. <style="Link"><link="helpers">Helpers</link></style> with less agency than <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style> do not have their own <style="CurrentLink">Privileged Abilities</style> but can provide players with <style="CurrentLink">Privileged Abilities</style> through offering services. As the effects of <style="Link"><link="power-ups">Power-Ups</link></style> usually are under <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limits</link></style>, the effects they have on <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style> can more easily be controlled than for other types of <style="CurrentLink">Privileged Abilities</style>. It is quite common in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Strategy%20Games">Strategy Games</link></style> such as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Civilization%20(video%20game)%20series">Civilization series</link></style> to provide (temporary) <style="CurrentLink">Privileged Abilities</style> by <style="Link"><link="unlocking">Unlocking</link></style> specific parts of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Technology%20Trees">Technology Trees</link></style>. Becoming <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Neighbors">Neighbors</link></style> is a requirement for making the <style="CurrentLink">Privileged Abilities</style> often found in <style="Link"><link="massively-single-player-online-games">Massively Single-Player Online Games</link></style> which allow players to make <style="Link"><link="altruistic-actions">Altruistic Actions</link></style> in other players' <style="Link"><link="private-game-spaces">Private Game Spaces</link></style>. <style="CurrentLink">Privileged Abilities</style> may also appear due to <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> inflicted on other players that take away <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style> from them; the effect of losing your knights in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Chess">Chess</link></style> while your opponent still has them can be seen as your opponent having the <style="CurrentLink">Privileged Abilities</style> of making knights move. A specific form of <style="CurrentLink">Privileged Abilities</style> found only in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> is the <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style> to be able to relieve other players' from their state of <style="Link"><link="helplessness">Helplessness</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="sanctioned-cheating">Sanctioned Cheating</link></style> is a special case where the players - sometimes at a potential risk - can give themselves <style="CurrentLink">Privileged Abilities</style> through performing actions that are seen as at least somewhat doubtful.

The question of who has access to <style="CurrentLink">Privileged Abilities</style> can be split into the questions of what <style="Link"><link="focus-loci">Focus Loci</link></style> provides the action and which players have access to the action. In games with <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, the <style="CurrentLink">Privileged Abilities</style> can be tied to these and losing the <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> results in losing the <style="CurrentLink">Privileged Abilities</style> as well, but when players play these instead of use them, i.e. <style="Link"><link="player-characters">Player Characters</link></style>, the <style="CurrentLink">Privileged Abilities</style> may be used to make these exceptional. When using <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> representing <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> as players' <style="Link"><link="focus-loci">Focus Loci</link></style>, the <style="CurrentLink">Privileged Abilities</style> can be represented by <style="Link"><link="skills">Skills</link></style> to allow further modulation of the <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style>. Making <style="CurrentLink">Privileged Abilities</style> depend on the access to <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style> (e.g. <style="Link"><link="equipment">Equipment</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="weapons">Weapons</link></style>) can provide thematic explanations to introducing the <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style> during gameplay and can motivate <style="Link"><link="gain-ownership">Gain Ownership</link></style> goals. <style="Link"><link="transferable-items">Transferable Items</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> allow the <style="CurrentLink">Privileged Abilities</style> to shift between players by different forms of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Transfer%20of%20Control">Transfer of Control</link></style>, e. g., <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Stealing">Stealing</link></style> or doing certain kinds of <style="Link"><link="capture">Capture</link></style> actions - <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> can however also allow <style="CurrentLink">Privileged Abilities</style> to create <style="Link"><link="competence-areas">Competence Areas</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Games</link></style>. For games with <style="Link"><link="role-selection">Role Selection</link></style>, the actions allowed by a role may or may not be <style="CurrentLink">Privileged Abilities</style> depending on if other players are allowed to do the actions as well. However, if any players are allowed to perform the actions additional bonus <style="CurrentLink">Privileged Abilities</style> may be given to the choosers of roles as a way of encouraging people to pick roles rather than rely on others to choose them. The possibility of <style="Link"><link="player-planned-development">Player-Planned Development</link></style> affects <style="CurrentLink">Privileged Abilities</style> in that players may specifically aims for these, but the patterns also have a reversed relation in that the presences of one or more potential <style="CurrentLink">Privileged Abilities</style> can present important choices that need to be done as part of <style="Link"><link="player-planned-development">Player-Planned Development</link></style>.

The effect of which player has the <style="CurrentLink">Privileged Abilities</style> depends heavily upon whether the game involves <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style>. If so, <style="CurrentLink">Privileged Abilities</style> of players can be matched by the same <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style> in the other teams to create <style="Link"><link="team-balance">Team Balance</link></style>. This makes it possible for <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style> to have <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Symmetry">Symmetry</link></style> while providing <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Asymmetric%20Abilities">Asymmetric Abilities</link></style> within the <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style> and allows individual players to have game-controlled <style="Link"><link="competence-areas">Competence Areas</link></style> and thereby <style="Link"><link="functional-roles">Functional Roles</link></style>. In games without <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style> but with <style="Link"><link="cooperation">Cooperation</link></style>, the pattern can also support <style="Link"><link="competence-areas">Competence Areas</link></style> (and <style="Link"><link="functional-roles">Functional Roles</link></style>), while in games with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Conflicts">Conflicts</link></style> it is more likely to affect <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style>.

Possible effects on <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style> by <style="CurrentLink">Privileged Abilities</style> can be mitigated somewhat if they are part of the set of actions selectable by <style="Link"><link="budgeted-action-points">Budgeted Action Points</link></style> or making them have <style="Link"><link="cooldown">Cooldown</link></style> periods.

<style="CurrentLink">Privileged Abilities</style> are very often used to distinguish <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> in stories, and through this can be used to create <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style>. Further, when given as <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New Abilities</link></style> they can be important events that can also be part of <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Privileged Abilities</style> give players <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Empowerment">Empowerment</link></style> in games since they have <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style> that others do not. This is especially apparent in <style="Link"><link="self-facilitated-games">Self-Facilitated Games</link></style> that make use of <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style>, since the entire game state is controlled by them and all events in the game must be approved by them. When they are instead applied on <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style>, they can make these into <style="Link"><link="boss-monsters">Boss Monsters</link></style> and can provide <style="Link"><link="varied-gameplay">Varied Gameplay</link></style> in that they can behave differently than ordinary <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> and require <style="Link"><link="puzzle-solving">Puzzle Solving</link></style> since ordinary tactics may not be feasible.

By their very nature, <style="CurrentLink">Privileged Abilities</style> create <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Asymmetric%20Abilities">Asymmetric Abilities</link></style> between players and modulate the value of <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New Abilities</link></style>. This may easily affect <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style> negatively. When unsupervised by the game system, this can create greater and greater imbalances as gameplay progresses, but by actively modifying what <style="CurrentLink">Privileged Abilities</style> players have and when, e. g., by deciding the nature of <style="Link"><link="power-ups">Power-Ups</link></style> due to the positions of players in a racing game, the pattern can instead be used to create <style="Link"><link="handicap-systems">Handicap Systems</link></style> to support <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style>. In games with <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style>, this naturally can also affect <style="Link"><link="team-balance">Team Balance</link></style> but can also strengthen the strive to have <style="Link"><link="competence-areas">Competence Areas</link></style> as well as give them <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Game-Based%20Social%20Statuses">Game-Based Social Statuses</link></style>. Further, it can encourage players to work together to achieve <style="Link"><link="team-combos">Team Combos</link></style> even if no <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style> exist (i.e. it can work in any <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Game</link></style>). Beyond this, the pattern can support stimulated <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Social%20Interaction">Social Interaction</link></style>, as players usually need to engage in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Coordination">Coordination</link></style> to take full advantage of the set of actions they have. If the <style="CurrentLink">Privileged Abilities</style> are matched between the teams, <style="Link"><link="team-balance">Team Balance</link></style> can be achieved even though <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style> may not be.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Red%20Queen%20Dilemmas">Red Queen Dilemmas</link></style> can occur if players engaged in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Competition">Competition</link></style> can gain access to the same or balancing <style="CurrentLink">Privileged Abilities</style>, especially if there are series of <style="CurrentLink">Privileged Abilities</style> that have each other as prerequisites (e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Technology%20Trees">Technology Trees</link></style>).

<style="CurrentLink">Privileged Abilities</style> that are present from the beginning of the game not only create <style="Link"><link="asymmetric-starting-conditions">Asymmetric Starting Conditions</link></style> but also allow players to perform <style="Link"><link="strategic-planning">Strategic Planning</link></style>. Those <style="CurrentLink">Privileged Abilities</style> that are gained during gameplay in contrast increase the need for <style="Link"><link="tactical-planning">Tactical Planning</link></style> since players need to adjust to changes in their own or others capabilities.

In games with Parallel Lives, having some of the game elements that represent the different lives have Privileged Abilities make them have different value to players and thereby affect the overall game balance.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Asymmetric%20Abilities">Asymmetric Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="asymmetric-starting-conditions">Asymmetric Starting Conditions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="competence-areas">Competence Areas</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Empowerment">Empowerment</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="handicap-systems">Handicap Systems</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="interruptible-actions">Interruptible Actions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="renewable-resources">Renewable Resources</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="safe-havens">Safe Havens</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="strategic-planning">Strategic Planning</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="tactical-planning">Tactical Planning</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="abstract-player-constructs">Abstract Player Constructs</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="alarms">Alarms</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="diegetically-outstanding-features">Diegetically Outstanding Features</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="discard-piles">Discard Piles</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="drawing-stacks">Drawing Stacks</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="environmental-effects">Environmental Effects</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="fog-war">Fog of War</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="hands">Hands</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="health">Health</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="irreversible-events">Irreversible Events</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Jumping">Jumping</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="line-sight">Line of Sight</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="non-player-characters">Non-Player Characters</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="obstacles">Obstacles</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="parallel-lives">Parallel Lives</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="player-characters">Player Characters</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="player-planned-development">Player-Planned Development</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="role-selection">Role Selection</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="secret-resources">Secret Resources</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="self-facilitated-games">Self-Facilitated Games</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="warp-zones">Warp Zones</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="zone-control">Zone of Control</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="area-control">Area Control</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="chargers">Chargers</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="combos">Combos</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="construction">Construction</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="crafting">Crafting</link></style>,
